ground_truth: The storm is passing now, blown by the driving wind. The camera rises up to find Javert, the officer in charge of the convict workforce, looking on, his face rain-lashed and expressionless. Behind Javert, through the storm rain, there is a glimpse of a forest of half-built ships, their ribbed frames like great skeletons in the mist. In the foreground, convicts are at work on another ship that is almost completed, laboring in the crashing spray. With a last great heave, the lines of convicts haul the damaged ship onto the slipway. Javert stands above the men on the top of the dock, as lines of convicts labor beneath him on the steep steps of the dock wall. Javert nods to the guards, and they begin to form the chained men into lines to return to their prison. Javert approaches Jean Valjean, seeing him and pointing his stick at Valjean in silent command. Valjean stares back for a moment, defying him, then drops down into the seething water and re-emerges with the great mast in his hands, held over his head. His head breaks water with his bitter gaze still on Javert, as he throws the mast ashore in a deliberate display of strength. Valjean walks away, hardly able to take in that he is free at last. He makes his way up a rising track, a worn knapsack on his back, and strides down the long rising road, pulling his thin coat close around him against the cold winter wind. He comes to a stop at the top of the hill, where he sees, lit by the rising sun, a wide vista of fields and towns and villages stretching into the distance, with the snow-capped Alps beyond. He passes a long line of laborers working and approaches the overseer. Behind and below him lies Toulon at the sea's edge. The overseer notices shaved hair showing under his cap. Bewildered, fearful, and suspicious, Valjean gets up and goes with the Bishop into the house by the church, where there is a simple table on which are laid bread and wine with silver cutlery. The bishop's sister, Madame Baptistine, stands, and two silver candlesticks light the room, illuminating walls painted with religious scenes. Valjean hesitates, and the Bishop looks from the silver to Valjean. The old Bishop holds out the two silver candlesticks, and Valjean, utterly bewildered, takes them. Amazed, Valjean looks up, and silenced by the Bishop's gentle tones, the policemen turn and leave. Valjean takes out his yellow passport and stares at it, then kneels in the church. Slowly, he examines the yellow passport and raises it high, as if to the altar. Valjean stands and turns, walking fast to the door of the church.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description:
Here's the text transformed with synonyms:

The tempest is passing now, driven by the fierce gale. The camera ascends to locate Javert, the officer in charge of the prisoner workforce, observing, his visage rain-lashed and impassive. Behind Javert, through the storm rain, there is a glimpse of a woodland of half-constructed vessels, their ribbed frameworks like immense skeletons in the haze. In the foreground, prisoners are at toil on another vessel that is nearly finished, laboring in the crashing spray. With a final immense effort, the lines of prisoners drag the damaged vessel onto the slipway. Javert stands above the men on the top of the quay, as lines of prisoners toil beneath him on the steep steps of the quay wall. Javert nods to the sentries, and they commence to form the shackled men into lines to return to their penitentiary. Javert approaches Jean Valjean, observing him and pointing his baton at Valjean in tacit direction. Valjean gazes back for a moment, defying him, then drops into the roiling water and re-emerges with the immense mast in his hands, held over his head. His head breaks water with his bitter stare still on Javert, as he hurls the mast ashore in an intentional display of power. Valjean walks away, scarcely able to comprehend that he is free at last. He makes his way up a rising path, a worn haversack on his back, and strides down the long rising road, pulling his thin coat close around him against the cold winter gale. He comes to a halt at the top of the rise, where he sees, lit by the rising sun, a broad panorama of fields and towns and hamlets stretching into the distance, with the snow-capped Alps beyond. He passes a long line of laborers working and approaches the overseer. Behind and below him lies Toulon at the sea's edge. The overseer notices shaved hair showing under his cap. Bewildered, fearful, and suspicious, Valjean gets up and goes with the Bishop into the abode by the church, where there is a simple table on which are laid bread and wine with silver cutlery. The bishop's sister, Madame Baptistine, stands, and two silver candlesticks light the room, illuminating walls adorned with religious vistas. Valjean hesitates, and the Bishop looks from the silver to Valjean. The old Bishop extends the two silver candlesticks, and Valjean, utterly perplexed, takes them. Astonished, Valjean looks up, and silenced by the Bishop's gentle tones, the constables turn and depart. Valjean takes out his yellow permit and stares at it, then kneels in the church. Slowly, he inspects the yellow permit and raises it high, as if to the altar. Valjean stands and turns, walking swiftly to the door of the church.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The storm is now being passed by, as the driving wind blows it. The camera is raised up to find Javert, the officer in charge of the convict workforce, looking on, his face rain-lashed and expressionless. Behind Javert, through the storm rain, a forest of half-built ships can be glimpsed, their ribbed frames like great skeletons in the mist. In the foreground, another ship is being worked on by convicts, almost completed, laboring in the crashing spray. With a last great heave, the damaged ship is hauled onto the slipway by the lines of convicts. Above the men on the top of the dock, Javert stands, as the convict lines labor beneath him on the steep steps of the dock wall. The guards are nodded to by Javert, and they form the chained men into lines to return to their prison. Jean Valjean is approached by Javert, who sees him and points his stick at Valjean in silent command. Valjean stares back for a moment, defying him, then he drops down into the seething water and re-emerges with the great mast held over his head. His head breaks water with his bitter gaze still on Javert as the mast is thrown ashore by him in a deliberate display of strength. Hardly able to take in that he is free at last, Valjean walks away. Up a rising track, he makes his way, a worn knapsack on his back, and strides down the long rising road, his thin coat pulled close around him against the cold winter wind. At the top of the hill, he comes to a stop, where lit by the rising sun, a wide vista of fields and towns and villages stretches into the distance, with the snow-capped Alps beyond. He passes a long line of laborers working and approaches the overseer. Behind and below him, Toulon lies at the sea's edge. Under his cap, shaved hair is noticed by the overseer. Bewildered, fearful, and suspicious, Valjean gets up and goes with the Bishop into the house by the church, where bread and wine with silver cutlery are laid on a simple table. Standing, Madame Baptistine, the bishop's sister, is present, and the room is lit by two silver candlesticks, illuminating walls painted with religious scenes. Valjean hesitates, and the Bishop looks from the silver to Valjean. The two silver candlesticks are held out by the old Bishop, and Valjean, utterly bewildered, takes them. Amazed, Valjean looks up, and silenced by the Bishop's gentle tones, the policemen turn and leave. His yellow passport is taken out by Valjean, who stares at it, then kneels in the church. The yellow passport is slowly examined and raised high by him, as if to the altar. Valjean stands and turns, walking fast to the door of the church.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: The storm subsides, driven by fierce winds. The camera reveals Javert, in charge of the convict workforce, his expression stoic and rain-lashed. Behind him, in the stormy rain, are half-built ship skeletons. Convicts work on an almost completed ship, laboring in crashing spray. With a final heave, they haul a damaged ship onto the slipway. Javert stands above them on the dock, watching guards form the chained convicts into lines for their prison return. He approaches Jean Valjean, silently commanding him with a stick. Valjean defies Javert, dives into the water, re-emerges with a mast over his head, and throws it ashore to display strength. Valjean, feeling free, walks up a track, a knapsack on his back, pulling his coat against the cold wind. At a hilltop, he sees a vista of fields, towns, and the distant snow-capped Alps. Passing laborers, he approaches an overseer. Toulon lies below at the sea's edge. The overseer notices Valjean's shaved hair under his cap. Bewildered and fearful, Valjean follows the Bishop into the house with a simple table set with bread, wine, and silver cutlery. Madame Baptistine stands as silver candlesticks light religious scenes on the walls. The Bishop offers the candlesticks to a bewildered Valjean. Amazed, Valjean is silenced by the Bishop’s gentle voice as policemen leave. With his yellow passport in hand, Valjean kneels in the church, then raises it high toward the altar before exiting swiftly.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: The storm subsides with strong winds as the camera focuses on Javert, the convict workforce officer, drenched and expressionless. Behind him, storm-lashed half-built ships loom like skeletal frames. Nearby, convicts labor on nearly finished ships, hauling damaged ones onto the slipway under Javert's watch. He signals guards to line the chained men for prison return. Javert confronts Jean Valjean, who defiantly retrieves a mast from the water, showcasing strength, before walking away, feeling his newfound freedom. He ascends a hill, viewing fields, towns, and the Alps. Passing laborers, he approaches an overseer, noticing his shaved head. Suspicious, Valjean enters the Bishop's house, seeing bread, wine, and silverware. Madame Baptistine stands by, illuminated by silver candlesticks. The Bishop offers Valjean the candlesticks; police leave, silenced by the Bishop's gentle voice. Valjean examines his yellow passport, raises it to the altar, and exits the church.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: The storm, which has been wreaking havoc, is now beginning to pass, pushed along by the relentless force of the driving wind. The camera ascends, lifting its perspective to reveal Javert, the officer in command of the convict workforce. His face, lashed by the relentless rain, remains utterly expressionless as he observes the scene. Behind Javert, through the torrential storm rain, there is a fleeting glimpse of a forest of half-constructed ships. Their ribbed frames rise eerily through the mist like enormous skeletons. In the foreground, convicts are toiling away on another vessel that is nearing completion, laboring intensely amidst the crashing spray. With one final great effort, the lines of convicts manage to haul the damaged ship onto the slipway. Javert stands in a position of authority above the men, stationed on top of the dock. Below him, lines of convicts toil on the steep steps of the dock wall. Javert gives a nod to the guards, signaling them to start organizing the chained men into lines to be escorted back to their prison cells. Javert then approaches Jean Valjean, fixes his gaze on him, and points his stick at Valjean, silently commanding compliance. Valjean meets his gaze for a moment, defying Javert with silent determination. He then plunges into the roiling water and re-emerges triumphantly, holding the large mast over his head. His head breaks the water's surface, his eyes still locked in a bitter stare on Javert, as he deliberately tosses the mast ashore in a powerful demonstration of strength. Valjean walks away, barely able to comprehend that he is finally free. He makes his way up a rising track, a worn knapsack on his back, and strides purposefully along the long, ascending road, pulling his thin coat tightly around him to shield against the biting cold of the winter wind. He comes to a halt at the crest of a hill, where the rising sun illuminates a vast panorama of fields and towns and villages stretched out into the distance, with the majestic, snow-capped Alps looming beyond. Passing a long line of laborers engaged in their work, he approaches the overseer. Behind him, and below, Toulon lies at the sea's edge. The overseer catches sight of the shaved hair peeking out from beneath Valjean's cap. Bewildered, fearful, and filled with suspicion, Valjean rises and accompanies the Bishop into the house next to the church, which houses a simple table adorned with bread and wine alongside silver cutlery. The bishop's sister, Madame Baptistine, stands nearby, and two silver candlesticks cast a warm light over the room, illuminating walls beautifully painted with religious scenes. Valjean hesitates, glancing from the silver to the Bishop, who calmly holds out the two silver candlesticks. Utterly bewildered, Valjean accepts them, his astonishment evident. He looks up, silenced by the Bishop's gentle tones, and the policemen, influenced by this unexpected kindness, turn away and leave. Valjean retrieves his yellow passport, staring at it intently before kneeling in the church. Slowly and deliberately, he examines the yellow passport and raises it high, as if in a gesture of offering to the altar. Valjean stands resolutely and turns, walking briskly to the church's door, stepping into the new chapter of his life.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
The formidable storm, which has been causing significant damage and turmoil, is now gradually beginning to pass, urged along by the unyielding and powerful force of the driving wind. The camera gracefully ascends, shifting its viewpoint upward to unveil Javert, the officer who commands the convict workforce with an air of authority. His face, continually lashed by the relentless and unending rain, remains utterly expressionless and stoic as he observes the unfolding scene before him. Behind Javert, through the torrential downpour that persists in the storm, there appears a fleeting glimpse of a forest of half-constructed ships, their skeletal, ribbed frames eerily rising through the mist like enormous skeletons of long-lost creatures. In the foreground, a small army of convicts is diligently toiling away on another vessel that is nearing completion, laboring intensely amidst the relentless crashing spray.

With one final, monumental effort, the long lines of convicts manage to haul the damaged ship onto the slipway. Javert stands in a commanding position of authority above the men, stationed on top of the dock in a domineering stance. Below him, the long lines of weary convicts toil on the steep, wet steps of the dock wall. Javert gives a nod to the guards stationed nearby, signaling them to begin the task of organizing the chained men into orderly lines to be escorted back to their prison cells. Javert then approaches Jean Valjean, fixing his unwavering gaze upon him, and points his stick sternly at Valjean, silently commanding compliance. Valjean meets his gaze for a moment, defiantly staring back at Javert with silent determination. He then plunges into the tumultuous, roiling water and re-emerges triumphantly, holding the large mast defiantly over his head. His head breaks the water's churning surface, his eyes still locked in a bitter, challenging stare on Javert, as he deliberately and powerfully tosses the mast ashore in a grand demonstration of his immense strength.

Valjean walks away, barely able to comprehend the reality that he is finally free from the chains that bound him. He makes his way up a rising track, with a worn knapsack slung across his back, and strides purposefully along the long, ascending road, pulling his thin coat tightly around him in an effort to shield himself against the biting cold of the unforgiving winter wind. He comes to a halt at the crest of a hill, where the rising sun illuminates a vast, breathtaking panorama of fields, towns, and villages stretched out into the seemingly endless distance, with the majestic, snow-capped Alps looming beyond as a backdrop. Passing a long line of laborers who are deeply engaged in their work, he approaches the overseer. Behind him and below, the city of Toulon lies at the sea's edge, a reminder of the world he has left behind. The overseer catches sight of the shaved hair peeking out from beneath Valjean's cap. Bewildered, filled with fear and suspicion, Valjean rises and accompanies the Bishop into the house adjacent to the church, which houses a simple table adorned with bread and wine, alongside silver cutlery.

The bishop's sister, Madame Baptistine, stands nearby, and two silver candlesticks cast a warm, inviting light over the room, illuminating the walls that are beautifully painted with scenes of religious significance. Valjean hesitates for a moment, glancing from the immaculate silver to the Bishop, who calmly and generously holds out the two silver candlesticks towards him. Utterly bewildered and overcome with amazement, Valjean accepts them, his astonishment and disbelief clearly evident on his face. He looks up, silenced by the Bishop's gentle and kind tones, and the policemen, influenced and softened by this unexpected act of kindness, turn away and leave the scene. Valjean retrieves his yellow passport, staring at it intently and contemplatively before kneeling in the church. Slowly and deliberately, he examines the yellow passport, raising it high as if in a gesture of offering to the altar. Valjean stands resolutely and turns, walking briskly to the church's door, stepping out purposefully into the new chapter of his life, filled with hope and possibility.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: The storm gradually loses its intensity, driven away by the relentless winds, as the camera smoothly ascends to capture Javert, the officer overseeing the convict workforce, who stands stoically, his face unflinching yet battered by the rain. Positioned behind Javert and barely visible through the relentless storm and rain, is a forest of half-constructed ships, their skeletal frames reaching skyward like colossal, mist-shrouded skeletons. In the immediate foreground, convicts toil tirelessly on another vessel, which nears completion, laboring against the backdrop of crashing spray. With one final, tremendous effort, the convicts collectively heave the damaged ship onto the slipway. From his vantage point atop the dock, Javert surveys the scene as the chain of convicts below him tirelessly labor up the steep steps of the dock wall. With a single nod, he silently communicates to the guards, who respond by organizing the chained convicts into orderly lines, preparing them to march back to their prison cells. Javert strides purposefully toward Jean Valjean, fixing his gaze upon him and extending his baton in a wordless command. For a brief, tense moment, Valjean locks eyes with Javert, silently challenging him, before diving into the turbulent waters, resurfacing with the majestic mast held aloft in a show of formidable strength. His eyes locked onto Javert, Valjean hurls the mast onto the shore with deliberate force. With a newfound sense of freedom, Valjean begins his journey, barely comprehending the reality of his liberation. He ascends a rising path, his worn knapsack slung over his shoulder, and strides down the long, sloping road, pulling his thin coat tightly around himself to ward off the biting winter wind. Upon reaching the summit of a hill, he pauses to take in a breathtaking panorama bathed in the light of the rising sun, revealing a vast expanse of fields, towns, and villages, stretching all the way to the distant, snow-covered Alps. He passes a line of laborers hard at work and approaches the overseer, while behind and below him, Toulon lies nestled by the sea. The overseer, taking note of Valjean's shaved hair peeking out from beneath his cap, regards him with a mix of confusion, fear, and suspicion. Overwhelmed, Valjean rises to follow the Bishop into the modest house by the church, where a simple table is set with bread, wine, and silver cutlery. Madame Baptistine, the Bishop's sister, stands by, while two silver candlesticks cast a warm glow across the room, illuminating walls adorned with religious imagery. Valjean hesitates, his eyes shifting from the silver to the Bishop, who extends the two silver candlesticks with a gentle gesture. Stunned into silence, Valjean accepts them, and the police, likewise subdued by the Bishop's gentle demeanor, depart without protest. Alone, Valjean retrieves his yellow passport, staring intently at it before kneeling in the church. He slowly raises the passport high, almost in supplication to the altar. Rising to his feet, Valjean turns and, with newfound resolve, swiftly makes his way to the door of the church.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: As the storm subsides, the camera captures Javert, the unyielding officer overseeing the convict workforce, standing amidst the rain, with half-built ship skeletons visible in the mist behind him. Convicts labor in the foreground, hauling a damaged ship onto the slipway. From his vantage point atop the dock, Javert signals the guards to form the convicts into lines for their return to prison. Approaching Valjean, Javert silently commands him with a pointed stick. Valjean defiantly meets Javert's gaze, plunges into the water, and re-emerges, hoisting the ship's mast above his head before casting it ashore in a display of strength, then walks away, embracing his newfound freedom. He ventures up a winding track, pulling his coat tighter against the cold wind, until he pauses to admire the expansive view of fields and towns, with the Alps in the background. Upon reaching a group of laborers, he is noticed by an overseer. Conflicted and apprehensive, Valjean follows the Bishop into a modestly furnished house where the Bishop, alongside his sister, Madame Baptistine, offers him hospitality. Overwhelmed by the Bishop's kindness, Valjean accepts two silver candlesticks, astonished by the gesture. Reflecting on his life, he examines his yellow passport, raises it toward the altar in the church, and, with newfound resolve, quickly exits.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The storm is passing now, blown by the driving wind that often heralds the end of summer's tumultuous weather. The camera rises up to find Javert, the officer in charge of the convict workforce in 19th-century France, looking on, his face rain-lashed and expressionless. Behind Javert, through the storm rain, there is a glimpse of a forest of half-built ships, their ribbed frames like great skeletons in the mist, reminiscent of Toulon's historical shipbuilding dockyards. In the foreground, convicts are at work on another ship that is almost completed, laboring in the crashing spray from the Mediterranean Sea. With a last great heave, the lines of convicts haul the damaged ship onto the slipway, a critical stage in ship construction for launching vessels into the water. Javert stands above the men on the top of the dock, as lines of convicts labor beneath him on the steep steps of the dock wall, a scene capturing the harsh discipline of life in prison labor camps. Javert nods to the guards, and they begin to form the chained men into lines to return to their prison, likely returning to Toulon's notorious fortress-prison. Javert approaches Jean Valjean, whose history of imprisonment for stealing a loaf of bread during a time of great need haunts him, seeing him and pointing his stick at Valjean in silent command. Valjean stares back for a moment, defying him, then drops down into the seething water and re-emerges with the great mast in his hands, held over his head. His head breaks water with his bitter gaze still on Javert, as he throws the mast ashore in a deliberate display of strength, a testament to his inner resilience and defiance. Valjean walks away, hardly able to take in that he is free at last after years of forced servitude. He makes his way up a rising track, a worn knapsack on his back, and strides down the long rising road, pulling his thin coat close around him against the cold winter wind that sweeps down from the nearby coastal hills. He comes to a stop at the top of the hill, where he sees, lit by the rising sun, a wide vista of fields and towns and villages stretching into the distance, with the snow-capped Alps beyond, a magnificent landscape symbolizing the freedom he yearns for. He passes a long line of laborers working on a project likely tied to regional agriculture and approaches the overseer. Behind and below him lies Toulon, a historically significant port city, at the sea's edge. The overseer notices shaved hair showing under his cap, a telltale sign of his recent incarceration. Bewildered, fearful, and suspicious, Valjean gets up and goes with the Bishop into the house by the church, a sanctuary of peace and forgiveness, where there is a simple table on which are laid bread and wine with silver cutlery. The bishop's sister, Madame Baptistine, stands, and two silver candlesticks light the room, illuminating walls painted with religious scenes, creating an atmosphere of divine grace. Valjean hesitates, and the Bishop looks from the silver to Valjean, offering a chance for redemption. The old Bishop holds out the two silver candlesticks, and Valjean, utterly bewildered, takes them, his first encounter with genuine kindness in many years. Amazed, Valjean looks up, and silenced by the Bishop's gentle tones, the policemen turn and leave, showing the power of compassion to alter rigid judgment. Valjean takes out his yellow passport, a document marking him as an ex-convict, and stares at it, then kneels in the church, overwhelmed by the Bishop's mercy. Slowly, he examines the yellow passport and raises it high, as if to the altar, making a symbolic gesture toward starting anew. Valjean stands and turns, walking fast to the door of the church, determined to transform his life.

The camera rises up to find Javert the officer in charge of the convict workforce looking on his face rainlashed and expressionless. Behind Javert through the storm rain there is a glimpse of a forest of halfbuilt ships their ribbed frames like great skeletons in the mist. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. He comes to a stop at the top of the hill where he sees lit by the rising sun a wide vista of fields and towns and villages stretching into the distance with the snowcapped Alps beyond. He passes a long line of laborers working and approaches the overseer. Behind and below him lies Toulon at the sea's edge. The overseer notices shaved hair showing under his cap. Bewildered fearful and suspicious Valjean gets up and goes with the Bishop into the house by the church where there is a simple table on which are laid bread and wine with silver cutlery. The bishop's sister Madame Baptistine stands and two silver candlesticks light the room illuminating walls painted with religious scenes. Valjean hesitates and the Bishop looks from the silver to Valjean. The old Bishop holds out the two silver candlesticks and Valjean utterly bewildered takes them. Amazed Valjean looks up and silenced by the Bishop's gentle tones. the policemen turn and leave. Valjean takes out his yellow passport and stares at it then kneels in the church. Slowly he examines the yellow passport and raises it high as if to the altar. Valjean stands and turns walking fast to the door of the church.

On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. He comes to a stop at the top of the hill where he sees lit by the rising sun a wide vista of fields and towns and villages stretching into the distance with the snowcapped Alps beyond. He passes a long line of laborers working and approaches the overseer. Behind and below him lies Toulon at the sea's edge. The overseer notices shaved hair showing under his cap. Bewildered fearful and suspicious Valjean gets up and goes with the Bishop into the house by the church where there is a simple table on which are laid bread and wine with silver cutlery. The bishop's sister Madame Baptistine stands and two silver candlesticks light the room illuminating walls painted with religious scenes. Valjean hesitates and the Bishop looks from the silver to Valjean. The old Bishop holds out the two silver candlesticks and Valjean utterly bewildered takes them. Amazed Valjean looks up and silenced by the Bishop's gentle tones. the policemen turn and leave. Valjean takes out his yellow passport and stares at it then kneels in the church. Slowly he examines the yellow passport and raises it high as if to the altar. Valjean stands and turns walking fast to the door of the church.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: The storm is passing now blown by the driving wind. The camera rises up to find Javert the officer in charge of the convict workforce looking on his face rainlashed and expressionless. Behind Javert through the storm rain there is a glimpse of a forest of halfbuilt ships their ribbed frames like great skeletons in the mist. In the foreground convicts are at work on another ship that is almost completed laboring in the crashing spray. With a last great heave the lines of convicts haul the damaged ship onto the slipway. Javert stands above the men on the top of the dock as lines of convicts labor beneath him on the steep steps of the dock wall. Valjean hesitates and the Bishop looks from the silver to Valjean. The old Bishop holds out the two silver candlesticks and Valjean utterly bewildered takes them. Amazed Valjean looks up and silenced by the Bishop's gentle tones. the policemen turn and leave. Valjean takes out his yellow passport and stares at it then kneels in the church. Slowly he examines the yellow passport and raises it high as if to the altar. Valjean stands and turns walking fast to the door of the church.

test_cases.description: The storm is passing now blown by the driving wind. The camera rises up to find Javert the officer in charge of the convict workforce looking on his face rainlashed and expressionless. Valjean takes out his yellow passport and stares at it then kneels in the church. Slowly he examines the yellow passport and raises it high as if to the altar. Valjean stands and turns walking fast to the door of the church.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The breeze is fading now, nudged by the playful breeze. The kite descends down to locate Zinnia, the gardener in charge of the flower orchestra, observing closely, her face sun-dappled and indifferent. Beyond Zinnia, through the gentle drizzle, there is a peek of a fjord of half-grown trees, their leafy branches like grand specters in the fog. In the backdrop, musicians are rehearsing on another tree that is nearly complete, singing in the rustling wind. With a final great toss, the chorus of musicians swing the broken instrument onto the pathway. Zinnia hovers beside the players on the edge of the field, as rows of musicians harmonize around her on the slippery slopes of the hillock. Zinnia blinks to the judges, and they start to gather the unchained players into rows to proceed to their dormitory. Zinnia addresses Jove, observing him and waving her pen at Jove in wordless order. Jove gazes back briefly, challenging her, then leaps into the swirling air and surfaces with the grand baton in his grasp, held above his shoulders. His shoulders crest air with his fierce glare still on Zinnia, as he hurls the baton landward in a purposeful exhibit of prowess. Jove marches onward, scarcely managing to comprehend that he is liberated finally. He travels his route up a descending path, a heavy rucksack on his shoulders, and paces along the winding descending street, clutching his wool scarf snug around him against the warm summer breeze. He pauses at the bottom of the valley, where he perceives, dim by the setting moon, a narrow panorama of gardens and lakes and hamlets sprawling into the nearness, with the icy beach beyond. He wanders past a short group of dancers spinning and addresses the choreographer. Above and opposite him sprawls Calais at the mountain's base. The choreographer acknowledges messy whiskers peeking under his hat. Confused, eager, and curious, Jove hops up and journeys with the Monk into the barn beside the grove, where there is a lavish podium on which are arranged cheese and tea with porcelain dishes. The monk's cousin, Monsieur Harmony, reclines, and several gold lanterns brighten the barn, casting shadows painted with mythical images. Jove pauses, and the Monk glances from the gold to Jove. The young Monk gestures with several gold lanterns, and Jove, completely baffled, grasps them. Astonished, Jove glances down, and quieted by the Monk's mellow tunes, the firefighters pivot and vanish. Jove tugs out his purple badge and marvels at it, then squats in the grove. Gradually, he peruses the purple badge and lowers it low, as if to the meadow. Jove crouches and spins, leaping slowly to the window of the grove.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: The storm subsides as Javert, the officer overseeing the convicts, stands stoically amid rain-lashed winds. Convicts labor on nearly completed ships, hauling a damaged vessel onto the slipway. Javert signals to the guards to line up the chained men for their return to prison. He confronts Jean Valjean, who defies him, diving into the water and emerging with a ship's mast in a display of strength. Freed at last, Valjean heads up a rising track, clutching his thin coat against the cold, and reaches a hilltop with a vista of fields and snow-capped Alps. Passing workers, he encounters an overseer. Fearful and suspicious, Valjean follows the Bishop into his home. There, the Bishop offers him silver candlesticks, signaling kindness and trust. Valjean, bewildered, accepts them, silencing the policemen. Reflecting on his yellow passport, he kneels in the church, then departs quickly, a changed man.
